1:50 “…most of the rocket parts stay up…”

No, they do not. From the very beginning the vast majority, at least 95%, of the rocket falls down. A very small amount does stay up and presents a hazard.

What is missing from the entire video is the scale of the volume involved. From the surface to about 400km up is little concern since atmospheric drag empties it in months to a few years.

Geostationary orbit is 35,786 km. GPS orbit at several thousand km. Earth observation satellites are commonly in polar orbits at any altitude. That makes for a vast volume of orbital space. Worrying that they’ll collide is similar to worrying about dust motes in a stadium.

The fear probably stems from artistic renderings having to make diagrams usefully visible. Renderings are not to scale. The entirety of humanity’s space infrastructure would not even fill a single pixel if Earth was scaled to fill the screen. But renderings like to include the entire orbital track of every bit of debris.

If the worst were to happen it would render some range of altitudes a bit more hazardous than we like. It would just mean our new satellites would have to be placed above or below the offending altitude range.

Just going to say it, every single one of the solutions is unfeasible. Magnets would be both too heavy to push into space and most likely not strong enough. The nets would tear apart or would be more like tarps if you needed to catch the smaller pieces. The lasers would need too much energy, and the harpoons would be hard to aim. The electromagnets would still probably be the best solution, though.

My solution is to have a large, flat, sheet of kevlar or some other hard to break material (It would have a large metal frame with kevlar in the middle) and with a weak magnet to hold it in place. This setup would catch all of the particles and then would rotate itself to fling the debris at a large object with gravity, preferably Venus (Venus' atmosphere would dissolve the metal, and it's close). This works because since there's no atmosphere in space, the debris would travel continuously forever until it was stopped by a planet. The device would also not have to be too accurate, since Venus' gravitational field would capture it if the debris went near it. And if not, there's plenty of space for it to spread out.

Obviously, this wastes all the material in space, but I don't think it's worth it economically to have to send something into space just to extract a relatively little amount of metal. Also, almost all of the metal would burn up in the atmosphere anyway.

This isn't fully accurate and seems a little sensationalism.  Yes, debris is a problem in space, but it is not and will unlikely ever be the catastrophe this video is suggesting for several reasons.  1) Debris doesn't stay up there forever as there is drag that causes everything in LEO space to lower over time.  2) Most of the junk is well tracked (i.e. a toolbag that floated away from the ISS and entered Earth's atmosphere about 8 months later).  3) Low Earth Orbit (LEO) is not just one plane where everything sits, it is a volume.  When a satellite is nearing its end of mission it is expected to lower to an orbit where it can reenter in less than 25 years (a graveyard orbit). 4) Our infrastructure satellites (i.e. GPS) are not in LEO.  i.e. the Starlink satellites are flying around 1,100km, GPS satellites are at about 20,200km, and some even geostationary at around 36,000km above the surface; For reference the ISS is around 420km. 5) Space has a lot of space. See, here's the thing -- stuff in orbit that's too small to track is too small to target with a vapourising laser or plasma weapon. At some point we're gonna have to be able to safely cross this minefield, for lack of a more appropriately accurate description, and firing millions of laser beams or plasma bolts at millions of targets per minute just won't cut it. We can't waste that kind of energy on point defence. But if you imagine a magnetic field projected ahead of a vessel trying to push its way though on its way to Luna or Mars, that field can magnetically sweep that debris and detritus aside and make a safe path for the spacecraft to travel. Only once you clear that debris field can you safely engage the Alcubierre drive and warp to Mars or the other planets in this system or others.

Recently, China acknowledged that their rockets have no re-entry computers and don't really care where they fall. They've already badly damaged one of their cities with rocket debris. And no one wants a repeat of the Skylab incident, though our tech is better than it was 40ish years ago. We'd need to designate a kind of NEO space infrastructure graveyard in an ocean somewhere, maybe the Pacific since it's so massive. Taking a 1,000 mile trip, in order to save “a few minutes” just about every map service would send me 86 miles down a 1.5 lane mountain road instead of deviating 90 miles down a proper 8-lane highway through population centers. As you can imagine, during Christmas-time, this “fastest route” generally added hours as the mountain roads were nigh undriveable.

If we get desperate enough, it might be quicker and more cost effective to guide a metallic asteroid into a near miss. If we chose the right asteroid and lined it up properly in relation to the moon, the debris would impact and make craters, effectively making the asteroid a sweeping magnet that then proceeds out of our orbit. If it does get to that worst case scenario then any mission we send to clean it up gets riskier each moment it's up there. Going straight through the shell of debris to collect an asteroid means less time spent in the debris with a chance of contributing to the pile. Much higher return on investment if successful.

Eh I'm not sure this is going to be an actual problem. The diameter of low earth orbit is nearly double that of earth. There's trillions of objects and animals and bugs and we can move around freely without stepping on one with every step. The distance between most of these objects is massive. Not ideal to have the chance to hit something up there, but the chances of doing so are astronomical. Kind of a dumb thing to worry about. This is all based on a projection most likely, but most computer projections are wildly innacurate and tend to just go exponential. Reality tends not to have that kind of exponential growth. Even if space had a trillion objects, it's still far less than on the surface and still would probably be very large gaps, say the size of entire countries or more.

I guess the author forgot to mention  "relative" speed. Coupled with the exaggeration of "criss crossing" trajectories there is little concern. It is not like you are standing still trying to cross a busy highway. Although the speeds are high, "relative" speed is negligible. Two objects, no matter how fast they are going, if they are going the same speed and direction, pose NO threat of collision. And to GET into space where these other objects are, you HAVE to get to their speed to achieve the same orbit. So if you have to meet their speed to achieve even being there, then the logic is clear, the relative speed is ZERO. This video is complete fantasy!

Actually you could just armour spacecraft to resist small debris. While the debris may be travelling at velocities that will allow it to penetrate just about anything, the projectile will usually disintegrate once contact is made with the first layer of material. So one solution is what is called "spaced armour", making the superstructure out of multiple layers of material separated from each other by pockets of air. Once debris makes contact with the first layer, it will puncture it, but the projectile will break up and scatter, losing much of its energy by the time it impacts the second layer. In fact we already do this in the form of Whipple Shields on the ISS. The ISS was once hit by a piece of debris going many times faster than the speed of sound, and yet, nobody was hurt, and no equipment was damaged, because the spaced armour prevented the debris from reaching the interior.

But there is hope!  Since Kessler raised this issue, we've gotten smarter about not polluting critical orbits like geosynchronous.  The recent Mission Extension Vehicle (MEV-1) docking with Intelsat 901 in February showed it's possible to dock with old satellites and move them around, for example to a disposal orbit.  Fully reusable spacecraft like Starship will produce no upper stage debris, and for interplanetary missions are likely to use very low orbits for orbital refilling (sub 300km) where any debris very rapidly deorbits.

Well...nice video but I think there are some mistakes.
1. Orbit speed is very fast (7.9km/s in LEO) but almost all debris in LEO, GTO, SSO are spinning in same way (because of earth's spin) so relative speed is not as fast as orbit speed.
2. Reusable rockets can't help this situation. Whether we reuse boosters and first stage or not, they just fall down. Only final stage left in orbit and Launch services doesn't reuse it.

Due to relative speeds and the fact that speed = 0 doesn’t exist in space the problem isn’t facing a debris with differential speed of 30.000 km/h (which should also be converted in km/s = 8.3km/s) but a débris with uncontrollable parameters such as periapside & apoapside which can have a significant delta of speed when considering an object in transfert or orbiting object. This delta can easily be of some hundred m/s or some km/s in the worst case. 1km/s being a huge differential when considering an orbital speed.
Orbital speed is kind of locked to earths parameters. A ciracular orbit at 400km is faster than a circular orbit at 500km. So strictly speaking, going far up would make the relative speeds of object less significant but would take more fuel and cost more money.
Don’t imagine being hit by an orbiting object be like a plasma or something it’s false. At most it would be more like a rifle bullet.
This doesn’t change the problem but can be partially solved using armor just like the ISS. Bigger debris still representing a threat.

My idea to salvage larger pieces of space junk would be to send a gigantic cruiser out into space. I'm talking larger than any space vessel we've ever made, but in pieces. Once assembled, it would have a section for humans, a section for storage, and a section for retrieval/processing.

The human bridge would consist of the usual needs any astronaut would require. A place to store and prepare food; sleeping closets, etc.

The collection part of the ship would feature a trawling retrieval system. Think cast net fishing that could either be dragged behind the vessel, or aimed, targeted and launched out. Once the material was snagged it would pull materials back into the hull and drop them off into a compactor, or a disassembly station. In this station, something like satellites could be manually pulled apart for electronics, solar panels, and the like. Any scrap metal would be discarded and sent to the compactor.

Once in the compactor, the metal would be compressed to the tightest point possible, then transported to the storage hull. Aside from any metallic scrap pressed into a cube like a crushed car, anything that was salvageable could be placed into a container and stored carefully within, like a giant warehouse.

When the vessel reaches maximum storage, it would take aim at the earth and launch the storage hull back to the surface where it could emptied and its materials salvaged for further use. Afterwards, another storage hull could be launched up, or the original one could be sent up after being emptied to continue the cycle.

Quite frankly, Earth is a pretty nice place, not a prison. Although my engineering perspective is that space travel and satellite networks have some great upsides for science, our chemical rocket propulsion is woefully under-powered for effective exploration of the cosmos. We also have some very serious matters on Earth to attend to regarding how to halt accidentally terraforming our own planet with greenhouse gas emissions, which current rocket propulsion does not help in the matter. This may not be a popular opinion, but a Kessler cascade event may not be all that bad to take a break for a century to develop warp drive or faster propulsion and to get our own house in order. Yes, it would suck without scientific satellite measurements or GPS, but it would also shatter some of these myths that a moon or Mars base is any sort of moral or effective solution to escape a destroyed Earth in the near term.

Since I fear that any satellites that are sent into orbit to combat the spread of tiny space debris would get overwhelmed before they could make a net gain impact, I have an idea to deal with the problem of countless little chunks of space debris in a much cheaper manner (especially if Kessler Syndrome is in full effect already):


1. Send a rocket on a trajectory so straight upwards (like, say, 90 degrees from the ground) that even if it traveled high enough to be past geostationary orbit range, it would still fall right back to Earth, and collide with it (thus preventing it from creating more space debris).
2. Fill that rocket with a payload consisting of so much compressed gas that, when released from the rocket (in a manner akin to a crop-dusting plane), it would blanket an area of at least a square mile with gas, which thanks to the rocket's trajectory, would fall back to Earth along with the rocket.
3. While the gas is in space, any small debris that pass through it would be slowed down by the gas, potentially causing them to slow down enough that they'll fall back to the Earth's atmosphere.

A lot of this is fear mongering. Do these things travel super fast in space? Sure. BUT SO ARE YOU. You're at orbital speeds, EVERYTHING is fast. If you're in the same orbit as a piece of junk, and therefore travelling at the same speed, it's impossible to hit each other.

As for things on different orbits, you yourself admitted that space is super empty. Something like tiny satellite hitting something the size of a baseball has such a small probability, that a so-called "domino effect" would be extremely rare. It's difficult as it is to get things close together when we're TRYING to dock them together, and that's with much larger objects. Saying that "random chance" could lead to the destruction of 50 satellites in a year is possible, but improbable to the highest degree.

This is a bit misleading, the problem is presented as much worse then it is and the way orbital mechanics works its incredibly hard for 2 things to collide without alot of coordination. So while yes debris is in orbit and it can hit things it is incredibly unlikely even in a dense debris area which the earth is not, given earth's massive size the amount of debris in orbit is nothing. A low earth orbit is huge, bigger then you would think. it would be like the chances of 2 bullets colliding in a war, sure it happens, but even with billions of rounds fired only about 2-3 confirmed incidents have been found. It's certainly important to keep the earths orbit clean, but it's not going to be a problem for a very long time. We can't even get the right kind of intercepts you get from debris when we want it to happen, so the chances of it happening by chance are stupidly low. A guided missile hitting an ICBM has a low enough chance of hitting such high speed intercepts.

There's a single-season anime called Planetes. I bought the manga a few years back and it's still one of my favorite hard-scifi stories out there.

It's about a space-debris collection crew - where humanity deemed it necessary after a collision ended up in a massive loss of life. The Kessler syndrome, or a collision-cascade is later on featured in the story. Pretty underrated and is worth watching in its English dub.

Cleanup efforts seem essential, but how do you fund them? Why would any one government or company assume that responsibility over this shared territory? "Altruism" is too hopeful an answer for my cynical heart.
So how do we motivate someone to go into business cleaning up space? How do we make it profitable?
The only business model that springs to mind would be some kind of satellite insurance. Basically, have satellite owners pay this company for space junk insurance. The insurer uses some of the proceeds to fund cleanup projects like the nets, harpoons, and magnetic repulsers described in the video. With every piece of space junk eliminated, their likelihood of having to pay a claim for a destroyed satellite goes down.
Of course, if they do too good of a job, no one needs insurance anymore and they go out of business.
I didn't say it was a perfect solution!

Only place where there are many rocket stages are junk orbits in higher orbits, like junk orbit near geostationary orbit. And it is not a big issue for now. Due to certain doctrines lasers would never get approved. It is illegal for any countries (with the capabilities) to weaponize space. Lasers would definitely be viewed as a threat to target countries rather than to "Clean up" space debris. Even these other ideas of catching space debris with nets or "harpoons" would be very difficult to approve. Any country with assets in space could take these ideas as potential threats to their satellite constellation. Which could lead to violent actions. My opinion, start investing into reusable rockets. It'll be decades before we could figure out how to clean up space debris. I'm not saying to stop trying to come up with ideas on how to. We probably don't even possess the current technology to even pull off such a proposal. Therefore, invest into research and expand on the technology for reusable rockets so that we could minimize or eliminate cluttering up space even more.

OK, but let's use ad absurdum analysis on this problem: Once the trap sprang and there is a more or less uniform "junksphere" in LEO, frequent collisions will continue to happen among the particles comprising it; Each time there is a collision, a tiny amount of rest kinetic energy is converted into heat and radiated away, and a tiny amount of mass is evaporated and blown away by the solar wind. A sort of friction will happen inside the layer until it is synchronized and it all rotates as one homogeneous body, in same direction and with same velocity. Once it stabilizes, we can devise launches and missions which will have same speed and direction, and then we can start gradually emptying the "junksphere", or aggregating all particles into a small moon and use it as a satellite, or series of even smaller moons which will be sent down into thicker atmospheric layers to burn up.

The problem with the "clean up space" ideas is that there's a good chance that some nations will object to the current plans shown in this video, and with good reason: If you put a satellite into orbit that has, for example, a laser that can ablate other satellites to knock them out of orbit, what then is the functional difference between using it on junk vs. using it on another nation's satellites to secure a strategic or economic advantage? How do you build a junk-killing satellite that's not just as easily a satellite-killer satellite? Weaponizing space, even inadvertently, is a dangerous path to start down, so the big question to solve first is how to avoid that. I'm not sure what the answer is.

This is not really a problem in the sense of long term outcomes. We don’t need to capture junk. There’s more than enough atmosphere to resolve everything in the long run. It’s only sad for human lifetime outcomes. And in truly a worst case scenario, lasers aren’t even the best solution - we can vaporize a captured comet or two, and the gasses will brake things sufficiently to resolve orbiting debris in a few hundred years. Plus this would slightly reduce incident solar radiation, so it might be a bit of a climate change aid. Satellite debris isn’t a great filter. It’s just a very annoying problem that can ruin a lot of businesses for humankind. It’s a money problem, a convenience problem, and a space problem. But it doesn’t even doom exploration - it just would mean some of our space ships would be killed leaving orbit. We have billions of humans so as callous as it is to say this, this would not be a doomsday scenario. It’s just bad. Already we kill more humans on earth with famine, pollution, war, and other self inflicted problems.

This video was full of misinformation and falsities.

* GPS satellites are not in danger, they're too high.
* There are not 3-4 satellites being destroyed every year.
* Rockets don't leave their upper stages in LEO.
* And finally, stuff in LEO de-orbits on the order of months to years, occasionally decades, but definitely not centuries.

At the 400km orbit that ISS is at for example, ISS drops by 2km per month, and would de-orbit within a couple years if it was ever left alone.

Actually, a serious proposal. Orbit a sheet. Like a thin, mylar sheet, perhaps a mile square/round, 90 degrees to its orbit. Calculate the orbit so that it does not cross the path of any active satellites during its lifetime. It would get impacted by debris, large and small, that presumably would puncture it easily. However, these hits would, even though the mylar is thin, a lot of energy would be generated, which means the orbital path of the debris would be altered, presumably slowed. And thus make them deorbit much faster than if left alone. The sheet could be deployed by one of those pizza box size satellites, then after a year or so, the same satellite, attached to the sheet say by a corner, fires and deorbits both itself and the sheet. The satellite does not have to do anything but drag itself back into the atmosphere, where it burns up (just like the debris it targets).


If you make the sheet circular, the satellite can be attached in the middle and deploy the sheet just by spinning and then release the sheet, which deploys from centrifugal force. Then the small satellite stays attached at the center until the time comes to deorbit the sheet.

I see some problems with this statement.
First, the debris, just like the old satellites, would eventually fall back to earth due to air resistance, so it won't just stay and stack up.
Second, the debris are not moving in those fast speeds relative to the new spacecrafts. They would probably be moving in the same direction and around the same speed (as some directions require less resources than others), so collisions are much less probable and a lot less dangerous.
Of course the problem still exists, but maybe it is not so bad...

For people saying that the odds of a piece of space debris actually hitting another piece fast enough to damage it (due to similar or identical trajectories/orbits, meaning relative velocity is low) is "so low that it's not even worth worrying about", there's one thing that needs to be considered:

If one bit of space dust/debris is floating around up there, in a spot where it's capable of destroying a satellite, then....... that's enough.

If one satellite gets destroyed, then the debris that results from that collision wouldn't necessarily be moving in the same direction, at the same velocity. This seems obvious to me, but maybe I'm missing something. Imagine a car crash: The tiny little car pieces flung off by the collision go in every direction, not uniformly in the direction the car was moving, and at the same velocity. Physics is complicated, to put it simply.

So if that space debris is, for example, slowed by ~30%? Then the_relative_ velocity of the same satellite piece, compared to another (completely intact) satellite is roughly 10,000km/h slower.

That's like crashing into a car going 60, when you're going 100 miles an hour.

Space debris doesn't have to be moving in the exact opposite orbit to be absolutely devastating to the structural integrity of a satellite that it collides with.

It's not like a "Space Apocalypse" or anything, it's just a serious issue that can't just be hand-waved away because you don't think it's a big deal now, and probably won't be for a while (Hmm, where have I heard that, before?).

That's all I'm saying.

wanna learn how to make lemon cake..? well its your lucky day
Ingredients:
1/2 pound (2 sticks) unsalted butter, at room temperature
2 1/2 cups granulated sugar, divided
4 extra-large eggs, at room temperature
1/3 cup grated lemon zest (6 to 8 large lemons)
3 cups flour
1/2 teaspoon baking powder
1/2 teaspoon baking soda
1 teaspoon kosher salt
3/4 cup freshly squeezed lemon juice, divided
3/4 cup buttermilk, at room temperature
1 teaspoon pure vanilla extract
For the glaze:
2 cups confectioners' sugar, sifted
3 1/2 tablespoons freshly squeezed lemon juice

Instructions:
Step 1: Preheat the oven to 350 degrees F. Grease and flour 2 (8 1/2 by 4 1/4 by 2 1/2-inch) loaf pans. You may also line the bottom with parchment paper, if desired.
Step 2: Cream the butter and 2 cups granulated sugar in the bowl of an electric mixer fitted with the paddle attachment, until light and fluffy, about 5 minutes. With the mixer on medium speed, add the eggs, 1 at a time, and the lemon zest.
Step 3: Sift together the flour, baking powder, baking soda, and salt in a bowl. In another bowl, combine 1/4 cup lemon juice, the buttermilk, and vanilla. Add the flour and buttermilk mixtures alternately to the batter, beginning and ending with the flour. Divide the batter evenly between the pans, smooth the tops, and bake for 45 minutes to 1 hour, until a cake tester comes out clean.
Step 4: Combine 1/2 cup granulated sugar with 1/2 cup lemon juice in a small saucepan and cook over low heat until the sugar dissolves. When the cakes are done, allow to cool for 10 minutes. Remove the cakes from the pans and set them on a rack set over a tray or sheet pan; spoon the lemon syrup over them. Allow the cakes to cool completely.
Step 5:For the glaze, combine the confectioners' sugar and the lemon juice in a bowl, mixing with a wire whisk until smooth. Pour over the tops of the cakes and allow the glaze to drizzle down the sides

A lot of this is wrong. Most comm satellites are in geostationary orbit and not LEO. At the end of their service lifetime, the remaining fuel is used to push the satellites a couple hundred km out of geo orbit.

Yes there is a lot of space junk out there, but there are formal processes for disposal.

However, LEO constellations are becoming more popular for the future because they are much smaller satellites and cost less than geostationary ones. LEO constellations utilize multiple smaller satellites to cover a service area versus a single and large geo satellite. Yes, there will me more LEO satellites out there that pose a risk but again as I said above, there are formal processes to dispose of them at the end of their lifetime.

Also, the rocket stages never even reach orbit. They fall and burn up in the atmosphere (unless they are the reusable first stage used by SpaceX). So they aren’t necessarily floating space junk as the video says.

I actually think Kessler syndrome is extremely unlikely and this video seems a bit misleading: "Once in orbit, it's very hard to get out of orbit ... you're sort of locked in here forever" this is very inaccurate for low earth orbit (LEO) objects. It only takes about 100 m/s of retrograde deltaV (~1.3% of total velocity) to bring the periapsis of an object orbiting at the level of the ISS down into the upper atmosphere, thus burning up in half of an orbital period.

Given the massive amount of kinetic energy converted into heat during these collisions, the average velocity of all particles in the system would decrease significantly.

Space junk and Kessler syndrome is a real problem, but I wish the video made it clear that the ISS being "just a few hundred kilometers above the surface" (ISS is 400 km above surface) cannot indeed "stay up for centuries" as the video claimed. At this height there's non-trivial amount of atmospheric drag and by most estimates the ISS will de-orbit in 2 years or so if it doesn't perform boosts. The orbits that are problematic are usually higher, say 800km or so, since they do take a much longer time to de-orbit naturally.

1. It does not take centuries for a satellite to deorbit from LEO, it takes years to decades.
2. GPS, GLONASS, BeiDou, and Galileo are all in Medium-Earth Orbit, 1000 miles higher than Low-Earth Orbit.
3. Communications satellites are generally in Geostationary orbit, over 22000 miles higher than Low-Earth Orbit and generally stationary relative to one another.
4. When a satellites is hit by something tiny, it does not explode. It is like saying that firing a bullet at something metal will make it explode into a bunch of pieces, which is simply not the case at ballistic speeds.
4. No mention of the term Kessler Syndrome, the common name for this particular phenomenon.

Can we please not gloss over how big space is? LEO is from
100km-2,000km. This is equal to 4/3*pi*(2000^3 - 100^3), which is about
33 billion cubic kilometers.

Now using the stats in the video, lets see how much space the debris
take up:

2,600 satellites = 2,000 * 30 (generous estimate) = 60,000 m^3
10,000 objects size of monitors = 10,000*7m^3 = 70,000 m^3
20,000 objects size of apples = 20,000*104.5cm^3 = 2,090m ^3
500,000 objects size of marbles = 500,000* 2cm^3 = 1,000 m^3
100,000,000 objects smaller than marbles = 100,000,000 * 1cm^3 = 100,000
m ^3

add it all up to get 233km^3, which is A FUCKTON LESS THAN 33 billion km
^3. It is about .00007% of the space to be precise. To put this into
perspective, all of that mass could fit into ONE American football
stadium with a ton of space left over. There isn't even that much of a
problem if existing space debris gets broken up into smaller chunks
because the volume will stay constant and then deteriorate over time as
the atmosphere takes care of it.

I am sorry, but there are several misleading inaccuracies in the video. To name the most glaring, objects in low Earth orbit DO NOT STAY THERE FOREVER (or for centuries)! At distances under ~600 km, the outer vestiges of Earth's atmosphere still create atmospheric drag; the orbital decay of the ISS at roughly 400 km orbit is 2 km per MONTH, for instance. This means that most space junk within this area will decay fairly quickly, i.e. within the span of several years. Objects higher up would take longer, but lower sections should get clean within a few years.
Also, the geostationary orbit is where the key communication infrastructure is at and it remains largely unaffected by the space junk problem. GPS satellites orbit lower, but still well above low Earth orbit.
There is no doubt that space junk is a problem, but this scaremongering isn't the best way to raise alarm about this issue. You're just crying wolf, potentially complicating solutions when the excrement really hits the fan.
EDIT: I am not crapping on Kurzgesagt, I like their videos, but they should make certain things in this video more clear, even if they don't really support the "apocalyptic" proposition of this video.

We can’t look far enough, and there’s actually something very interesting happening that’s going to make it even more impossible.
The universe is expanding. As it expands the objects farthest away from us that we can we can see are moving away faster than the light from them can travel to us. Space is actually stretching faster than light can can cross it. This forms a horizon we cannot see past. Now, since it’s still expanding, this horizon is still getting smaller. Things are expanding away from us faster than light, making them move beyond the horizon. The light from those objects will now never reach us. Now, because visual information can only travel at the speed of light for all purpose those objects no longer exist to us as material. We cannot ever, even if given infinite time, interact with, observe, or collect any information about them again. Because of physics anything beyond the horizon does not exist as far as we’re concerned. This isn’t just a thought process or something, these objects physically no longer exist within our reference frame anymore. Now, to sum up what all this means. There is a horizon, beyond which nothing physically exists from our perspective. This is what we call the observable universe. This horizon is closing in on us, eliminating more and more from our observable universe. As a result, we see less and less of the things that exist everyday. Our universe is getting smaller as it expands.

This video is indeed fear mongering. Sure, the numbers look intimidating, but what people need to understand is how gigantic orbital distances are. It's nothing like in "Gravity" where all the space stations are just around the corner and can be reached by flying an MMU for a couple of minutes.


More than that, the claim that 3 or 4 satellites are destroyed by space junk every year is utterly false. It's close approaches that are estimated at ONE per year, and not every collision results in complete destruction of the satellite since the satellites and the junk fly at approximately the same speed. As of 2009, only 4 collisions had been detected, and only one of them actually destroyed the satellite.

We also have to consider the fuel cost of launching multiple recovery/cleaning missions as a accidental method of restricting our exploration by creating a resource shortage. A variant on the harpoon and chute solution might just be the ticket. Loading a single launch mission with what's essentially a missile pod attached to RCS thrusters, loaded with a compliment of harpoons attached to spring release parachutes.

The cleanup craft, loaded with about 60(?) recovery missions worth of harpoons goes up to a target, lets say a largely intact, but non-functional satellite. It lines up the currently active barrel of the pod with the satellite, launches and embeds the harpoon in it's target, which then springs open into a large parachute once it's settled in to the satellite's momentum. The increased surface area also increases drag on the upper earth atmosphere, dragging the whole thing down into a dive where, if it's a legal size, it'll burn up harmlessly in the atmosphere.

Most debris circles the earth in the same direction more or less, so if we launch things in the same direction, collisions are much less destructive, and unlikely.

An even greater risk of space junk in orbit is the possibility of trapping an astroid, rather than an astronaut. Being heavy balls of rock with their own orbit, an astroid collision with space junk can be cataclysmic as the sheer weight of it can drag down billions of debris back in orbit, like a katamari ball of death that gets bigger on the way down.

Question: would higher orbit satellites be OK? A lot of our Comms satellites are sitting up in geostationary orbit so our earth based satellite receivers don't have to track them across the sky. Low Earth orbit only goes up to 2000km up and Geocentric is 35786km up. Granted there's a bunch of navigation satellites scattered through that region including GPS, but that's mostly upwards of 20 000km.

I mean, if we had a cloud of bullet sized metal whipping around in LEO, there'd probably be some significant interference in any signals being transmitted through, and not being able to put new equipment up would be bad, but I doubt we'd be quite as screwed on Earth as this video suggests.

Don't forget just blasting holes through the debris field if we really needed to. I think the best solution is to cover everything in ablative material and use ground based lasers. There would be no risk of failure due to damage like deorbiting engines, and large powerplants could be devoted to clean up. Not to mention a strong enough laser can be used to make a thermal laser rocket, which would have a higher specific impulse than chemical rockets with all the thrust. Let's also not forget to look at this from a capitalistic perspective. It's a weapon, but so is the debris if nobody cleans it up. That means there's a lower chance of retaliation if we attack other satellites.

Objects in higher orbits however aren't going anywhere and do have the potential to do significant damage.

You stated the satellites can be destroyed this way, but the satellites are moving at a similar speed, so the damage comparison given earlier is void.

Before anybody notes that they may be going opposite directions: the 30,000km/h speed can only stay that speed by going prograde direction, the same direction which all satellites are lauched.

I'm not saying it isn't possible, it clearly is, as satellites are being destroyed, but the problem is being blown way out of proportion.

Instead of a harpoon or net, ferromagnets may be best, if we can get the right amount of attraction.

Then you may only need less than 40 missions or so to clean up A class objects, and less than 200 for A & B class objects.

Not sure we can get around the fact that we need multiple massive sails to go around and collect, or deflect to a de-orbit path, the smaller debris, and would likely need to make them permanent missions.

I no joke wrote a college admission essay on this topic(On Nov 20). If anyone wants to read it here you go.

As the space industry grows each year, with launches every week, the space debris grows as well. In years to come, we will likely stop littering space using methods to prevent our spacecraft from becoming debris. In the meantime, there still needs to be a method in place to rid space of our junk. Many of the proposed methods to clearing debris requires lots of fuel or is limited to one time uses. An article written by NASA stated, “More than 500,000 pieces of debris are tracked as they orbit the Earth. They all travel at speeds up to 17,500 mph…” Only 4% of the debris is greater than the size of a softball, which makes deorbiting the wide range of sizes difficult. This is how we get into discussing theoretical options to removing debris.
Scientist are theorizing about a laser that shoots the debris to slow it down. The benefits of a laser, is that it is reusable, located on the ground for easy accessibility, and fast turnaround time. However, some fragments may not head towards Earth as planned. Instead their trajectory could be on course to collide with an operational spacecraft. This is why I propose we use a non-destructive laser.
The intent would be the same, but the debris would be in one piece until it burned in Earth’s atmosphere. The objective would be to push the debris towards Earth, which means the force has to come from a higher orbit than the debris. One way to accomplish this is to put a giant satellite in high orbit that can reflect the laser, enabling it to deorbit debris. Another option would be to put that same laser device in place of the reflector in space. Naturally, countries are not fond of having weapons in space. This would not be an issue since the laser can only “push” objects and not destroy them.
This laser technique alludes to the further uses of this technology. One allows spacecraft to sustain a low Earth orbit without having to waste energy, such as the ISS. I believe this is the future of deorbiting, and as every year passes we become closer to discovering that technology. So many questions have yet to be answered, which is why I want to resolve them.

It's a bit troubling to hear Kurzgesagt keep talking about space exploration when our civilization is steadily marching towards global collapse.

But if they really claim to inspire change, as their conclusions suggest, if they claim scientific accuracy and educational purpose, I think they should really take some responsibility, stop implying the possibility of future space exploration, and focus back on what may well put and end not only to space programs, but to the whole industrial civilization.

All I can find is a BBC article that says it is estimated one satellite a year is destroyed, with no examples and no link or source. All I can find is one single example from 2009 where a Russian satellite collided with another on launch. Seems implausible, but supposedly it happened. If there are a trillion pieces of space junk, it seems rational to think this is a threat, and being worried about the exponential expansion of junk seems reasonable as well. 1. Low Earth orbit debris does not stay up there for hundreds of years, it can in fact come down within months or years. The tiny amount of drag gradually slows it down until it no longer has the speed to stay in orbit. This is why the international space station needs to fire up small onboard engines every couple of months.

2. Although space debris is travelling very fast relative to Earth, it's relative velocity compared to other satellites is nowhere near 30,000 kmh.(the other satellites are travelling at about the same speed)

I am not trying to say that space debris is harmless, but it is not nearly as devastating as it is portrayed in this video.

To be fair, this effect, called the Kessler syndrome, should not last forever, maybe not even on a human timescale. Small debris has a very high surface to mass ratio, which means the drag will slow it down a lot more than larger space junk, especially in low earth orbit. Also, most of the debris should form a ring kinda like Saturn during it's creation, which can be avoided and removed more easily than a debris field over the entire surface. It's certainly annoying but probably not a prison that lasts forever.
Feel free to correct me if I'm wrong, for example about the assumed magnitude of the effects involved.

Considering that a lot of larger LEO debris is rocket parts and defunct satellites, recovery of that debris might be a good test for technology meant to be used for asteroid mining. Capturing the debris, safely returning the recovered materials to Earth, and protecting the mining operation from micro impacts are all issues just as relevant to mining asteroids as they are to recovering LEO debris. Plus, with LEO being much closer to us than asteroids, it'd be much easier to monitor progress, troubleshoot, and iterate on designs.

How many knew within the first couple seconds this was going to be a video about kessler syndrome?  I wonder about the practicality of a laser satellite.  Problem with ground sources of infrared radiation is going through miles of atmosphere to reach a target.  A laser satellite charged by solar panels or a lump of plutonium seems awsome until you consider the laser emitter wearing out & needing replacement.  How great it would be to have an automated drone targeting pieces of micro junk starting with highest risk of collision working down to low risk over several years.  It's certainly cheaper to use electrical energy to vaporise matter than produce & build rockets & fuel to intercept & deorbit debris.  It'll probably be a mix of these solutions with the large defuct satellites requiring direct interception while others can be swept by laser brooms.

The idea is to use laser, but not to vaporise the debris but to give it enough of a push such that its orbit  becomes strongly elliptical, with a minor axis length of ~100km. Oh uhm... where do i start. Orbital mechanics...
Please don't make people believe the pieces of debrie hit each other with 30000Km/h relative speed.
All things in an circular orbit at the same inclination move at the same speed (given they move in a prograde orbit). Yes Kessler Syndrome is a threat, but it is not like we aren't doing anything about it.
We try to minimize the risks. For example by moving obsolete satelites into a so called graveyard orbit.
What really is a problem is when states like china launch weapons into an retrograde orbit. You don't need any tugs anymore when they do that more often, bc then you have debrie going both directions. That is pretty much game over.
What really must be done is to make sure that all devices orbiting the earth have enough fuel to deorbit them once they become obsolete. An reverse apogee kick motor so to say.
To limit the costs the fuel (the deltaV) one only needs to reduce the perigee to a point where reasonable aerobreaking starts. Even if it takes weeks until the the deorbit is complete it would still be an improvement.
Tugs are simply too expensive. It is nice to think this up. But who's gonna stand up and yell "Yeah, here, i will pay for that!" ?

now if you think about it 100% reusable rockets seem not only necessary to build a mars colony, its also imperative to save ourselves from our own doom.. satellites should always be equipped with some type of propulsion like xenon ion engines so they can be aimed at the sun, or have small ships in orbit along the deadzone to collect the space junk and recycle them in orbit, soo many people who play kerbal space program already do this technique for all of their spent staging and defunct stations/satellites.. granted KSP is just a game but KSP is just a game that every space agency from NASA to the ESA plays in their free time, so its hardly out of their minds.. now if only elon musk could make a falcon heavy launch with a mobile salvage refinery ship to LEO that would be great.

edit: it would also be smart to make the interstage welded onto the 1st stage of the rocket so that it doesn't get left in orbit, spacex already does this but many others like the soyuz, ares, arian 5, and delta rockets dont, leaving interstage sections as well as fairings in orbit are very dangerous.. so even that daft idea that elon was thinking off that attempts to catch the fairing might actually be smart.. also its better to collect the space junk rather than throw it to the sun because a lot of satellites use rare earth metals like iridium, molybdenum, and beryllium which are quite rare on earth..

I usually love Kurzgesagt videos, but I think they painted a grimmer picture, then what reality is for the greater shock effect. While the space debris problem is real, with some wiki reading and calculations one can easily see, that even in the event of a chain-collision we would only have to wait 50 years, after that we could probably resume operations above LEO. Another thing is, that low earth orbit doesn't even really suffer from this problem, since orbital decay get's to everything within a sort amount of time (hours, days, weeks depending on the distance from Earth). Like the ISS is relatively safe at 400km (by design), since there isn't much debris at that height.
